Speaker: Speaker 1 (Donna Strickland)
Utterance: So I understand you're in grad school.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Donna Strickland)
Utterance: Where?

Speaker: Speaker 5 (Aditya - Grad Student)
Utterance: At NYU.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Donna Strickland)
Utterance: And what are you studying?

Speaker: Speaker 5 (Aditya - Grad Student)
Utterance: I'm studying soft matter physics,

Speaker: Speaker 5 (Aditya - Grad Student)
Utterance: which involves the physics of squishy stuff.

Speaker: Speaker 5 (Aditya - Grad Student)
Utterance: We make microswimmers in the laboratory

Speaker: Speaker 5 (Aditya - Grad Student)
Utterance: and we drive them with a laser.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Donna Strickland)
Utterance: And what kind of laser do you use?

Speaker: Speaker 5 (Aditya - Grad Student)
Utterance: We use a 10 watt laser, it's a fiber laser.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Donna Strickland)
Utterance: Do you know a lot about lasers?

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Donna Strickland)
Utterance: Or just about the laser that you use.

Speaker: Speaker 5 (Aditya - Grad Student)
Utterance: Not a lot, just a little bit.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Donna Strickland)
Utterance: Okay.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Donna Strickland)
Utterance: So this is about high intensity lasers.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Donna Strickland)
Utterance: Not only how do you make them,

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Donna Strickland)
Utterance: but what was really stopping them being made in both cases is non linear optics.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Donna Strickland)
Utterance: We wanna do something that requires a huge photon density application,

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Donna Strickland)
Utterance: and so that's how come we came up with chirped pulse amplification,

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Donna Strickland)
Utterance: so that we could stretch the pulse,

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Donna Strickland)
Utterance: safely amplify it, then compress it at the end,

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Donna Strickland)
Utterance: and then we're ready to do whatever we want at the end.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Donna Strickland)
Utterance: So what do you think the main difference is between the continuous wave laser that you have that runs at 10 watts and a chirped pulse amplifier?

Speaker: Speaker 5 (Aditya - Grad Student)
Utterance: I feel like the continuous laser delivers power at a continuous rate,

Speaker: Speaker 5 (Aditya - Grad Student)
Utterance: whereas you want all that power to be delivered in a really, really short time with your amplification.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Donna Strickland)
Utterance: And so we get the power with a lot less energy 'cause its power is energy per unit time.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Donna Strickland)
Utterance: So we aren't depositing much energy in comparison.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Donna Strickland)
Utterance: Can I just ask, 'cause you are using the thermal process of it heating up,

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Donna Strickland)
Utterance: but have you ever had the opportunity to use laser tweezers?

Speaker: Speaker 5 (Aditya - Grad Student)
Utterance: I have, yeah.

Speaker: Speaker 5 (Aditya - Grad Student)
Utterance: We use optical tweezers to trap particles in solution.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Donna Strickland)
Utterance: And twirl the motors or not twirl the motors?

Speaker: Speaker 5 (Aditya - Grad Student)
Utterance: No, I haven't worked with that.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Donna Strickland)
Utterance: You haven't?

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Donna Strickland)
Utterance: Okay.

Speaker: Speaker 5 (Aditya - Grad Student)
Utterance: So I was always curious, how much further, like what higher power can we go now?

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Donna Strickland)
Utterance: So chirped pulse amplification took us sort of from, we were at 10 to the 12,

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Donna Strickland)
Utterance: but when I was working the 10 to the 12 sort of sat on a football sized field.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Donna Strickland)
Utterance: It was a kilojoule laser with a nanosecond pulse.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Donna Strickland)
Utterance: And we brought it down to something we call tabletop terawatt.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Donna Strickland)
Utterance: So it was the same terawatt but now it was one joule and one picosecond,

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Donna Strickland)
Utterance: so it could fit on a basic optical bench like you would have in your lab.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Donna Strickland)
Utterance: We were able to take that up to, I think the record is right around somewhere between 10 to the 22 and 10 to the 23 watts per square centimeter.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Donna Strickland)
Utterance: So then in going forward, one of the holy grails is can we reach 10 to the 29 watts per square centimeter?

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Donna Strickland)
Utterance: So we still have six orders.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Donna Strickland)
Utterance: So we've gone from 10 to the 12 to 10 to the 23.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Donna Strickland)
Utterance: So we've done 11 orders,

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Donna Strickland)
Utterance: so you think six isn't so much harder.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Donna Strickland)
Utterance: I have to tell you, over time, it's rolling over.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Donna Strickland)
Utterance: We need another Nobel Prize winning idea.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Donna Strickland)
Utterance: But if we get out there, that's where, if you focus the intensity,

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Donna Strickland)
Utterance: the energy in that volume is enough to break the vacuum.

Speaker: Speaker 5 (Aditya - Grad Student)
Utterance: We could probably use this to drive chemical reactions at a very, very specific spot.

Speaker: Speaker 5 (Aditya - Grad Student)
Utterance: Like if we want to target just a single cell in the body.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Donna Strickland)
Utterance: Yes.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Donna Strickland)
Utterance: And maybe what, do pump-probe spectroscopy and watch the cell?

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Donna Strickland)
Utterance: Or to ionize it?

Speaker: Speaker 5 (Aditya - Grad Student)
Utterance: I mean I was thinking more on the lines of if we want to, let's say destroy one cell,

Speaker: Speaker 5 (Aditya - Grad Student)
Utterance: like a tumor cell or something like that.

Speaker: Speaker 5 (Aditya - Grad Student)
Utterance: So that the neighboring areas are not affected but just the cell burns.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Donna Strickland)
Utterance: I don't know if people are working on that because I'm not so much in the medical field,

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Donna Strickland)
Utterance: but I should look into that and see if that's a possibility.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Donna Strickland)
Utterance: So after hearing about high intensity lasers,

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Donna Strickland)
Utterance: can you think about next time you go back to the lab and you're wondering how to do something in the lab with lasers,

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Donna Strickland)
Utterance: can you see how short pulses might help you?

Speaker: Speaker 5 (Aditya - Grad Student)
Utterance: I think short pulses might help in my experiment in the sense that if I drive my swimmers with a continuous wave as opposed to a pulsed wave,

Speaker: Speaker 5 (Aditya - Grad Student)
Utterance: maybe a continuous wave would heat up the sample too much

Speaker: Speaker 5 (Aditya - Grad Student)
Utterance: and a pulse laser would deliver power exactly where I need it so that I could run my experiment longer.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Donna Strickland)
Utterance: That's true.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Donna Strickland)
Utterance: Thank you very much.

Speaker: Speaker 5 (Aditya - Grad Student)
Utterance: Thank you, Donna.
